The 6-hour Police Standoff of
Korryn Gaines

On the morning of Aug. 1, officers with the Baltimore County Police Department arrived at the Randallstown apartment of Korryn Gaines to serve warrants on her and her fiance, Kareem Courtney. After a standoff that lasted about six hours, Gaines was dead from police gunfire. County prosecutors would rule the shooting justified, and no charges would be filed against officers.

Through a public records request, The Baltimore Sun obtained and reviewed a trove of evidence in the case, from officer statements and police radio chatter to crime scene photographs and videos, pictures and audio recordings taken by Gaines during the standoff.

This presentation explores what we found: a stark, unvarnished and rare look at the death of a young black woman at the hands of police, from both parties’ perspectives.

Begin

9:10 a.m

The standoff begins

About 9:10 a.m., officers arrived at Gaines’ Randallstown apartment to serve warrants on her and her fiance, Kareem Courtney. Her warrant was for her failure to appear in court on charges related to a traffic stop in March. His warrant was for an assault charge based on a domestic violence report filed by Gaines in June. The officers kicked in the door of the apartment, then retreated to the outer hallway after Gaines, who had a shotgun, told them to leave. Courtney would soon exit the apartment with the couple’s 1-year-old daughter; Gaines remained inside with her 5-year-old son. At 9:41 a.m., officers reported a barricade situation.

The front door of Korryn Gaines’ apartment

Still of apartment complex

Prev

Next

10:24 a.m.

"If you have a better system here, I’m listening."

As the minutes passed, officers outside of Gaines’ apartment door tried to convince her to put down her gun and come out. Gaines didn’t budge. Outside, police amassed more resources. Gaines began recording parts of her conversations with police on her phone, including one in which an officer promises her she would not be hurt, and that he just wanted to talk to her.

Apartment layout blueprint

  • 10:23 a.m. - Gaines appears seated with gun, yelling at officers

Prev

Next

12:24 p.m

"The devil at my door"

Hours passed by. Gaines continued to record video on her phone, and post on social media. At 12:24 p.m., she recorded a video saying the "devil" was at her door, referring to police. Outside, officers obtained a warrant for her arrest on assault, resisting arrest and other charges related to her allegedly pointing her gun at the officers who had initially entered the apartment. Family members tried to reach Gaines, as did a police negotiator, by phone. At one point, Gaines had her son Kodi film an officer in the doorway to the apartment -- who tried to motion to the boy to come out, to no avail.

Still from a video recorded on Korryn Gaines’ phone shows an officer in the doorway of her apartment during the standoff with police.

    (2:48)

Prev

Next

1:41 p.m

"They’re stealing the moment"

Gaines continued to become more emotional. In a phone conversation she recorded with a police negotiator, she described her March traffic stop as traumatic, saying that she had been mistreated by police and that it had led to her miscarriage of twins. The negotiator told Gaines that the police, at this point, could not simply leave. Gaines said the officers outside her door were the same as those who previously mistreated her. She told the negotiator about Courtney being in prison during the first months of their daughter’s life, and said the police were again trying to disrupt their peaceful family life.

Police stage outside of Gaines’ Randallstown apartment building. (WJZ)

Multimedia

  • 1:41 p.m. - Korryn talking to 911/police

    (1:03)

  • 1:52 - 1:57 p.m. - Korryn talking to police negotiator

    (11:37)

Prev

Next

3:25 p.m.

"Shots fired!"

At some point, police shut down Gaines’ Facebook account, trying to limit her access to the outside world so she would focus on the negotiations. She recorded a video, shot from below, in which she is holding the shotgun at the ready. She bounces, shifting her weight from foot to foot, her son next to her. About 45 minutes later, an officer came across the police radio: "Shots fired!" In a subsequent statement to police, the officer who fired the shots, Officer Royce Ruby Jr., wrote that he first fired after Gaines had raised her gun in the direction of his fellow officers, because he feared for their lives. He wrote that he fired again, after entering the apartment, because Gaines had again raised her shotgun in his direction and he feared for both his life and the life of her son.

Audio transmission from SWAT around 3:25 p.m.

Multimedia

  • 2:40 p.m. - From below, holding shotgun up, shaking with Kodi

    (1:35)

  • 3:25 p.m. - "Back off ... shots fired ... get a medic"

    (1:40)

  • Officer Ruby’s statement/interview

  • 2 – 4 p.m. – Police transmission

    (12:12)

Prev

Next

After 3:2 p.m.

The standoff ends

After Gaines was shot multiple times, a medic was called into the apartment. Gaines was pronounced dead in the apartment’s kitchen. Kodi was taken to a hospital. Ruby submitted his weapon to a superior. Photographs show the apartment of a young family suddenly transformed into a crime scene: a police rifle leaning against a wall next to a box of Pampers diapers; a baby rocker feet from Gaines’ shotgun on the floor; and, a trail of blood leading out of the kitchen from Gaines’ lifeless body.

Still of officer’s gun, pampers

Still of Gaines’ shotgun

Next

Following weeks

The aftermath

In the hours, days and weeks that followed, Gaines’ killing became a national story. In September, Gaines’ family alleged police wrongdoing in the incident, and filed a lawsuit against the police. Shortly thereafter, Baltimore State’s Attorney Scott Shellenberger declined to file any charges against Ruby or any other officers involved in the incident. In mid-October, Baltimore County Executive Kevin Kamenetz announced that the Baltimore County Police Department would fast-track its efforts to equip county officers with body cameras.
